author: nishant0
content: Are there any downsides to allowing exited validators to rejoin the network as active validators again ?

author: ralexstokes
content: the main thing is that it complicates the protocol to have to recycle validator indices

author: ralexstokes
content: we use the validator index as a stand-in for the validator identity in several places

author: ralexstokes
content: and it ends up being cleaner/simpler to have a "one-way" lifecycle graph

author: ralexstokes
content: <@415109946682769408> has a talk on this

author: ralexstokes
content: you would end up adding loops to the lifecycle graph which just makes things more complex

author: ralexstokes
content: simple enough to just re-join as a new validator if that is what you wished to do

author: nishant0
content:
but their indexes would stay the same no ? the only thing that changes would be 
the current validator status.

But then their old balance will be stuck in the beacon chain doing nothing in that case

author: ralexstokes
content: afaiui there is some intention to allow more flexibility here in later phases

author: ralexstokes
content: right so the fields in the state tracking who is where in the lifecycle would need to be managed by more complex code

author: ralexstokes
content: we can start (esp in early phases) with the simple "naive" thing

author: carlbeek
content:
>simple enough to just re-join as a new validator if that is what you wished to do

With the caveat that doing so requires depositing at least 1 more ETH. But this could be fixed with a kind of modified transfer along the lines of `transfer_into_new_validator`

author: nishant0
content: I guess that could be something we can do for now in the time being. We did get some questions  on if there was any way to 'pause' your stake and resume it later if you choose to

author: ralexstokes
content: <@550420431744794624> you are pointing out that there is a "sub 1-ETH" territory where this isn't as simple as we would want?

author: ralexstokes
content: <@476250636548308992> yeah the "pause" thing is something i hear about a lot as well... there are a bunch of trade-offs here to consider around validator experience, protocol complexity and according to some regulatory uncertainty

author: ralexstokes
content: if it becomes clear we need to do something different to make an attractive validator experience then im confident we can sort it out

author: carlbeek
content: I have found that lot of the "pause" questions are from people thinking they will be slashed for going offline.

author: nishant0
content:
yeah there is a fair bit of misconceptions on it, but also it does help them feel safer and 
have a larger degree of control over their staking activity

author: carlbeek
content:
> <@550420431744794624> you are pointing out that there is a "sub 1-ETH" territory where this isn't as simple as we would want?

Not sure I follow. All I am trying to point out is that if you exit and want to start up again. The way to do it is to transfer to a new validator (index). To do so requires a validator to exist at this index which can only be the case if there was a previous deposit. This requires a minimum of 1 eth sent to the deposit contract.

author: nishant0
content:
They might not want to continously online for a long period of time, because managing your validator 
does require some amount of effort consistently

author: ralexstokes
content: gotcha

author: ralexstokes
content: i was even thinking phase 0 pre-transfer

author: jgm
content: There are no transfers in phase 0, though.  And would it not be simpler to just allow a validator to move from exited to active (assuming it has enough in terms of funds, of course)

author: carlbeek
content: It does mess with the issuance of indicies tho. The root in the deposit contract would also get out of sync

author: nishant0
content: Also does anyone have a link to <@415109946682769408> talk on validator lifecycles ? Seems like something quite relevant to this

author: ralexstokes
content: yeah i suppose that is the strongest argument to keep the (phase 0) status quo -- the deposit contract would have to change and there has been a lot of formal verification effort put into it so far

content: <@476250636548308992> she has given a few versions of the talk at various confernces -- edcon 2019 and devcon (this year i think)

author: protolambda
content: deposit index doesn't necessarily have to match validator index. I don't think the contract needs to change at all. Maybe client implementer tooling that makes the assumption.

author: ralexstokes
content: another thing to keep in mind when thinking about "validator index resuse" is how things differ across forks and how message interpretation across fork boundaries could be complicated by this

author: ralexstokes
content: that's fair, we are indexing by pubkey there

author: jgm
content: If the validator lifecycle changed the EXITED state to INACTIVE and allowed movement back to ACTIVE it's not really reusing an index, though

author: protolambda
content: Also note that we already support topups with deposits. Deposit index is bound to get out of sync with validator index on the first top up.
